commentBody:
No, no, no!

A PIT STOP is a brief stop, not an overnight stay in a hotel. 

This PIT STOP is an actual PIT STOP, at an auto race, where the driver stops to re-tire his race car. 

Re-tire-ment, get it?

@Sotto Voce -- Responding to your query to me yesterday on the Rex Parker blog: I think you need a Google email account in order to get your name in blue.  I don't really remember how I did it -- it was 10 years ago, but I do have a Google email as well as my (much more used) Yahoo account.  I suggest you put up a comment early on tomorrow's Rexblog asking for help and I'm sure some people far more tech-savvy than I am (a very low bar) will offer help.

(I'll be back to comment on Friday's puzzle in about 12 hours.)

Fun puzzle with lively clues, lots of fresh and interesting answers, and few three letter answers.  I solved it steadily by jumping all around.  I liked REFUSENIKS (maybe Bartleby was the first one).  I was also happy to see DEIRDRE (of the sorrows), which I remembered because I long ago wrote a paper on the treatment of the DEIRDRE legend in Irish literature.  Don‚Äôt let anybody tell you that a liberal arts education isn‚Äôt worthwhile.  But all puzzlers know that.

Because I like wearing an off-the-shoulder dress while working in the garden*, 1A could also have been:
SUNSCREEN
DEERFLIES
NEIGHBORS

(* ‚ÄúIs she joking?‚Äù PROBS!)

One of those puzzles that seemed impossible at first, then slowly, step by step, inch by inch, it got solved. I was a little surprised (?) to see OH LORD and DEAR GOD in the same puzzle, even if they had very different clues. It was nice to have OSSIE Davis instead of GEENA or BETTE (not that they would have fit the specific clue). And what Steve L said about PIT STOP.

I thought something quite blue was an Only Fans SCENE.

But that would have required me to "think so" in a different modern shorthand...

I always thought "bigwigs" were people of high, if not highest, rank. CEOs, company presidents, managing editors, directors, managers--people with a lot of authority and few, if any superiors. How does a Marine corporal--outranked by several levels of sergeants and all.officers, from 2nd Lieutenant on up--fit that description? (Cuevthe regular Defenders of Every Clue.)

Enjoyed this puzzle so much better than yesterday‚Äôs. Finished quickly, despite a slow start. Maybe because this feels like my generation‚Äôs puzzle (Gen X).

Steve L is right, Deb. PITSTOP was undoubtedly about a place to re-tire a race car üèéÔ∏è.

Fun fact: I haven‚Äôt owned a clothes DRYER since moving to Portugal two years ago. I wash my clothes in a fancy washing machine (m√°quina de lavar roupa, in the kitchen of course) and then take them onto an adjacent veranda where I hang them out to dry like a typical Portuguese person. It‚Äôs soooo relaxing and the clothes are so fresh! I save money and help the environment. The clothes last longer, too, I think. I never imagined myself doing this but here I am!

I was slowed down a bit in my solving due to my characteristic stubbornness, for example insisting on eRNURSE instead of ORNURSE.  Also, I was convinced Burna Boy‚Äôs genre would have been AFROrap instead of AFROPOP but that was GenX popping out instead of GenZ! 

Fun Friday üòä. Another good one, Colin!

Well I see the column's pit stop / retirement error has already been addressed (and I'm near certain we've seen this tire changing answer before).

"Doe" just seems plain wrong.  It's used jokingly (doe,  a deer) in the Sound of Music of course, but the note sound is written as "do", always, as far as I know.  Each note in the scale represented by two letters.

The only thing that held me up here was having "ER Nurse" and wondering for a while what de-gearing was.

"Handles differently?" was the best clue.  (Meanwhile veepstakes is kind of dumb, even if it's used by a lot of news media.). Anyhow, a good puzzle overall.

/Jesse Goldberg Wednesday 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
That was an exquisitely clued puzzle.

Any time a -NIK occasions a puzzle, I‚Äôm sold.

Admittedly crosswordese but I, I daresay, chortle.



cc: emu handler
Since, when I replace the rubber on my car I retyre it, I saw the PITA STOP as the place where cars that can go no further are retired from the race.
Great Friday puzzle. What a good week so far.

Good puzzle.
Thanks.

Nothing is more frustrating, especially to the dyslexia afflicted, than to finish a puzzle and learn that  ‚Äúat least one letter‚Äôs amiss‚Äù!!   Grrr‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

I did love the clues, though.

It took me an hour to finish this puzzle, but it was worth every minute.

I won't lie and say that, like yesterday, I was on the same wavelength or in flow, or that all was spilling out from my brain as if by magic.

It was, instead, a very intensely focused solve, furrowing my brows as I tried to unravel the clues, then sighing with relief at each correct entry. 

And so, steady as she goes, I weathered this storm of construction creativity, beautifully executed. 

I have a few more wrinkles now, but that's what brilliant misdirects will do. ([Nursery purchase] alone is responsible for three of those new forehead creases.) 

Thank you, Mr. Adams, for this OBSCENEly good puzzle!
The Mittens clue was a great diversion. Felt like the constructor was pawing with me!
SW corner was impossible. Gave up after 30 minutes. Managed the rest of the puzzle easily enough

Even when I dredged up fills so cleverly masked that I fell smart when I got them, and words I didn't know I knew‚ÄîDEIRDRE? where did that come from? GRODY? sounded right‚Äîthere were fills in this puzzle that I couldn't know: YOINKED? FROYO?; and I never imagined that an non-commissioned officer would be considered a bigwig in any branch of the service‚ÄîI spent an OBSCENE amount of time on the solve and had to go for help where I could find it. 

I do not often complain about the difficulty of a puzzle, and I'm sure others will say they were delighted with it, but this time I definitely did not have a good time.
Done in 11:35, beating my Friday average by 7 minutes. So many impressive clues here, and what a grid!! Kudos to the constructor and editor!!!

Dear Brutus, won't you come out and splay?
Dear Brutus, I have a brand new cat toy!
The veep is up, Chicago Sky wears blue;
blue's not obscene, so please don't sue!
Dear Brutus, won't you come out and splay?
Dear Brutus, watch our garish Tsar break ties

Dear Brutus, see his ranks of grody spies.
As rulers they'll go low, unreality's new NCOs: 
"The wall will be built with their pesos!"
Dear Brutus, won't you open up your eyes?

[Apologies to Prudence]

***

[A la Joplin's "Mercedes Benz"]

Oh Lord won't you buy me a trip to see Seoul?
I was writing a novel, fell down my own plot hole.
A refusenik all my lifetime, from Hanoi to mining coal.
So, oh, Lord, won't you buy me a trip to see Seoul?

Oh Lord, won't you elect me a Person-of-Color VP?
A garish relic who serves unreality just ain't for me
There's an OR nurse doing delivery every day until three
So oh Lord, won't you elect her a Person-of-Color VP?

(I was going to conclude with a version of Hunter Hayes' "Dear God" -- remember him, last seen playing the Natick Auditorium? -- but couldn't really redo his lyrics with puzzwords, so I'll just quote him instead...)

Here I go again
Three glasses in, countin' my sins
Home alone again
It's three in the mornin'
Just me and my demons at war again
So I'm callin' in, are you listenin'?

You made a man that's fragile
You made a heart that can break
You showed me the road less traveled
Knowin' I'm gonna run away
You make me love so hard
When everything I love just leaves...

Personally I found this a strange puzzle, very enjoyable in places and impossibly hard in others. I had to look up a few things, but even then the SW corner was just too much - I ended up turning on autocheck to resolve that area in reasonable time.

The crossing of _OINKED and FRO_O was a mystery for a while but then I came up with a Y to go there. Perhaps I have seen FROYO before in NYT puzzles? I can't remember. It's not something I've seen in Poland or Europe in general, anyway.

Also, what scale involves a DOE? Is it a play on do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-si-do, as a comment below implies? If so, it was incredibly arcane.

I wanted to ask about the enigmatic VEEPstakes, too, but Google explained it to me. I am not an ignoramus, and I am following the build up to your presidential elections (as Putin's neighbor I care about the result no less than you do, possibly), but I do it in the Guardian app, which being British/Australian does not use American slang.
I was so amused to see GRODY in the puzzle, I had to use it as my Wordle start word ! [bad idea]

Such a great puzzle! Not a single unreasonable answer, wonderful cluing.
Especially liked DEARGOD and OHLORD.
Fast and fresh. Great puzzle.

Embarrassing to say that I had spelled GRODY with a ‚Äòt‚Äô since the 80‚Äôs till, well, today. And tween girls need to spell GRODY, well, often. 

‚ÄòMarked Twain‚Äô was fantastic.
So good! I feel like we‚Äôve had a lot of great Fridays recently. DOGEARED and CATTOY were very well clued.

All around nice Friday puzzle. I loved the PIT STOP clue and it was fun seeing YOINKED again. [Marked Twain] for DOG EARED, and [They're made to measure] for RULERS were 2 other favorites. Please bear with the long link, but PROBE reminded me of this cartoon: https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgjtGhDl94xUCS0AOelRHCbySL9_90y0DsaMU0CsDR0CeUxPE0WgJjAK-Kw2700EacXZBMO_GYrlvNsFJiznZIzoXQ8cbJy7ayGtEOSf1fi134QOiLjbbfi4xhws5kSUizthTVSIjnr-ESYG57yguEuQaMdqX_LXqeuVdWaFZ_6m1EmJ

Streak hits 1000 today.

A special shoutout to what made it all possible -- hey, it's already been mentioned in today's puzzle:  retirement!  That, and Covid boredom.

Toughest puzzles of them all?  The ones before and after major surgery, which thankfully were Monday-Tuesday-Wednesday.

And the unexpected rewards ... for instance, where else would the idea to try bibimbap come from?
GRODY took me back to the 80s and my time as a valley girl (the Ottawa valley, that is).

One itty bitty (or is it itsy bitsy, or teeny weeny, not to mention teensy weensy) error: I had YOICKED instead of YOINKED. But I forgive myself, because IMO, these are not real words. I thought maybe CCO stood for Chief Commanding Officer. Come to think of it, I like my answer better. Isn't NCO a non-commissioned officer? Why would that be a big shot in the USMC?

'
'
'
'
'
So there!

Teeny weeny error number two: Forgetting to change skirts to SKORTS.

Nice one Colin.  Thank you

I hope Mandy Patinkin isn't doing the puzzle today. His wife is Kathryn Grody.

>
>
>
>
>
Emu challenge
I still don't see how "Makes fast" means "secures" and thus TIES.

I, a wordplay stan, loved the cluing, which was rich with it. 

I‚Äôd like to focus here on my two favorite clues, because they were original ‚Äì and, trust me, given the long history of crosswords, it‚Äôs hard to come up with an outstanding original clue.  

Today, I should mention, there were clues based on words ‚Äì ‚Äúhome‚Äù, ‚Äúhandle‚Äù, ‚Äúretirement‚Äù ‚Äì that have been punned on before in puzzles.  I, an experienced solver, smiled at these old friends.

But I wowed at two terrific clues that broke new ground:
[Alternative to hanging out?] for DRYER.
[Marked Twain] for DOGEARED.

A moment of appreciation, please.  These are crossword gold.

Joy from the cluing was buttressed by lovely answers: REFUSENIK, GARISH, PLOT HOLE, DOGEARED, DEAR GOD, GO POOF, SPLAY, YOINKED, ESTHETE.

Buttressed by resistance that satisfied my brain‚Äôs work ethic.  

And buttressed by hardly a whiff of junk amid all that white space in the grid.  Why all the white space despite the paucity of long answers?  Because there are only 29 black squares, even less than in the average Saturday puzzle.  

So, wit, beauty, bite, and grid-building chops ‚Äì a recipe for a stellar outing, which is what you delivered, Colin.  Bravo, and thank you!

I try to avoid the ‚Äúalternative to hanging out‚Äù whenever possible.

Unsurprisingly I found this a more Saturday than Friday level of difficulty, so wonder what tomorrow will bring.  Quite a wide range of interesting fill however.
My wife loves to watch me do the crossword every morning. She doesn‚Äôt usually chime in, but danged if she didn‚Äôt bust it wide open for me today, when she blurted out ‚Äúbra straps‚Äù

Totally up my alley.

Had I not been married to
eRNURSE 
for *way * too long, this would have 
been a very smooth and satisfying solve.

Oh, who am I kidding. 
It was anyway.

REFUSENIK was new to me, 
so thank goodness this wasn‚Äôt a 
fill-in-the-blank, but a 
crossword.

Chewy Friday with a creamy center!

Thank you Colin!

And‚Ä¶it‚Äôs Friday!

Well... two day losing streak for me. Can't remember the last time that happened. 

Just got completely stuck in a couple of places and couldn't work it all out. 

We'll see about tomorrow. 

..
With all respect to Deb Amien, I thought the [Occasion for retirement?]/PITSTOP clue referred to an auto racer's pit stop where the car gets a fresh set of tires (re-TIRE-ment).

Failed at the crossing of FROYO and YOINKED. Never heard of either, though I suppose FROYO has to do with frozen yogurt? Should have guessed that Y.

The rest was fine, but saw my latest streak GOPOOF in less than a week.

A very enjoyable puzzle.  I hit a dead end last night but after letting it simmer on the back burner of my brain overnight, it all came together in the morning as is so often the case.  
I agree with the complaints regarding NCO. I rejected it early and only used it when it was clear from the crosses.

For the longest time I stuck to tent as the camp covering  and OHdear as its neighbor. This lead me to coed for the traditional Scottish New Year‚Äôs Day gift which didn‚Äôt seem likely, but you know those Scots‚Ä¶

A fine Friday puzzle it was

Wow, that was HARD!  I really considered abandoning ship.  The "slangily" and "colloquially" expressed terms were seriously strange, not to mention the "summer snack" and the alternative spelling of a word often used to describe Oscar Wilde (14D).

Irish mythological heroine?  Psyche's lover? "Parasite" setting?  Golden bikini? --stakes?

I won't soon forget Colin Adams.  
My granny used to threaten to "snatch you bald-headed" if you persisted in naughty behavior...  It's just as well she didn't live long enough to see 43D appear in her daily crossword puzzle.  Colin's photo would look quite ...altered.

Great puzzle that needed figuring, rather than googling. I like DEARGOD and OHLORD in the same puzzle. (Though I had COAt rather than COAL initially - that's a great gift to signify warmth!) 
I love when the first thing that pops in my head turns out to be right - BRASTRAPS immediately, as I was struggling with mine this morning. GO POOF - wow, it was right! 
TGIF, everyone.

Phew.  Tough one for me. Had PROLY in for PROBS which tripped me up for a while on 44 and 49 down. 

And then ‚ÄúMarked Twain‚Äù, while I certainly admire the cluing creativity and admit it had me fooled for ages, I think it‚Äôs right on the fine line of ‚Äútricky vs unfairly misleading‚Äù as it pertains to part of speech of clue vs answer. I think ‚ÄúMarked a Twain‚Äù would have been fairer. I kept trying to find a noun ending with ‚ÄúAREA‚Äù that made sense. 

Otherwise solid fun challenge for a Friday.

A lengthy stay in the Emergency room gave me DE-GEARED--was this some weird nautical term for down-shifting into second? And the neologism "VEEPstakes" made for a post-solve look-up. Yesterday we had OSCAR WILDE; today we had (A)ESTHETE (how I wanted to enter the digraph √Ü as a rebus!) Yesterday we had TOGAE, which prompted my comment about assassins hiding daggers in theirs; today BRUTUS made his appearance. *** *** The novelist/poet Robert Graves and I have difficulty thinking of "Psyche and Eros" as a genuine myth--in the sense of a shared cultural meme. Rather, it's a contrived allegory of the Soul and Desire, most of the details (full of PLOT_HOLES, dontcha know) invented by the Roman novelist Apuleius. At the end of story, after all Psyche's trials, Hermes, in his role of psychopomp, conducts her up into Olympus, and to her wedding with Eros. How pretty! My close friend Tom--a composer and painter--recently passed away. In his will, he bequeathed me a painting which he titled "Chromapotheosis," itself a deconstruction of the marble of Hermes and Psyche, by 19th c. sculptor Reinhold Begas, which stands in the National Gallery in Berlin (https://tinyurl.com/6bprxxb6). It hangs proudly in our living room. So you see, I have a bit of emotional attachment to the story.
Wonderful puzzle . Aren't Mittens an alternative name for cat paws ? That's how I got there - perhaps just fortuitous . Loved the cluing in this one- -keep it up !

Let's put PROBS inside the same (hopefully padlocked) cupboard that holds ADORBS.  And while we're at it, let's shove GRODY in there too.  GROSS means the exact same thing, takes less long to say, and is even a real word.

I hear it gets really cold in Scotland.  May I have a COAT, please, instead of COAL?  Thank you.

A word about YOINKED -- which isn't a word either.  It could have been BOINKED or ZOINKED of JOINKED for all I knew, but I guessed that the snack with the swirl might be FROYO as in frozen yogurt.  It was just a complete guess, but it kept me from having a DNF.

Things I know nothing about:  the Tower of Hanoi puzzle; Gold Bond and its ingredients; Wizkid and Burna Boy.   Another puzzle that I feel invites certain demographic groups in -- while telling the rest of us to drop dead.

I did love the clue for DOGEARED, so there's that.

Nice and just chewy enough.
I had momentary hang-ups at 
34D tent? TARP
50A gross? GRODY
59A arm? ANT

Strands was surprisingly easy today. Surprising because that is not my baileywick at all. But I spotted the spangram immediately.
(No spoiler comments, plz, until after "view all replies".)
Strands #180
‚ÄúLet's play‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ

The three little kittens They lost their mittens And they began to cry https://beta.poetryfoundation.org/poems/46968/the-three-little-kittens-they-lost-their-mittens I kind of love that the Poetry Foundation has nursey rhymes.

Just the other day I had to disable an ADBLOCKER that was causing issues, so I should have gotten that one even faster! Enjoyed the puzzle. Always like wordplay. Disliked YOINKED and GRODY though. Happy Friday!
oh, the absolute joy of filling in GRODY
Did anyone else suggest that PITSTOP didn't refer to sleeping but to changing the tires in a NASCAR race?
Ivan the Terrible was the first TSAR, not Ivan the Great.
This has to do with yesterday‚Äôs puzzle (and many others), but am I the only one who‚Äôs confused by AAH and AHH?

DEARGOD is nearby DOGEARED today.
DEARGOD is nearly DOGEARED (these days).

And TALC GOPOOF.

Enjoyable clueing today, breezy answers.
@debamlen, I interpreted 8D differently. In a car race, new tires are put on at a pit stop, hence ‚Äúretirement.‚Äù

Fun! Quick one for me today, but I took several wrong turns getting there. 

Is there/should there be a designation for old slang rather than new slang? I don't think anyone has said GRODY--even ironically--since I was in high school, but PROBS and YOINKED are fair game today.

Is something still considered slang if it's no longer used?

Strands #180
‚ÄúLet's play‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ

I‚Äôm not interested in the subject of this one, and it was mostly a matter of finding random words. But for people who enjoy the Spangram, this might be fun.

In her column, Deb said "I have no idea why Ms. Zappa was dressed as if she was going to a garden party, while the backup dancers were dressed as if they had just stumbled out of a Jane Fonda workout video".

The answer to the second part is: it was the 80s... Jane Fonda Workout videos were all the rage, and lots of people thought it was an attractive, cool look.

I think the answer to the first part is (mostly): she was underage at the time, so wouldn't wear/wasn't allowed on TV wearing, the dancer gear. But also partly: she's a Zappa, so was predisposed to doing something unexpected.

In defense of YOINK(ED):

One or the other has been in the puzzle 5 times since 2018, and 3 times this year alone. 

Usage example:

"When my sister got up to answer the phone, Jingles (our cat at the time) jumped up on S****'s  chair, YOINKED a chicken breast from her plate, then ran into the kitchen and threw it in her bowl".  

For years, in the retelling of the story, we've been saying "Jingles swiped" or "Jingles snatched". YOINK really gets to the heart of not only the taking but the stealth and skill involved.

All I am saying is give YOINKED a chance.

I just thought I would mention that Moon Unit Zappa has just in the last couple of weeks come out with a memoir entitled, ‚ÄúEarth to Moon‚Äù.  It reflects on her childhood in the shadow of the bigger-than-life Frank and her upbringing in an unconventional household in 1970‚Äôs -80‚Äôs Los Angeles. I opted to get the audio  version which she narrates. I‚Äôm only part way through, but I‚Äôd recommend it for any aging Zappa fans out there. I know we had a discussion here about the Mothers of Invention ‚ÄúPhlorescent Leach and Eddie‚Äù at the Fillmore East at one point, but I don‚Äôt remember the context.

Yesterday's comment on bringing the puzzles into modern times had me reflecting on a theory I've had.  Don't laugh (or please do), but I think the downfall of American education started when The Ed Sullivan Show was cancelled.
   Here we were, the whole family, different generations watching an hour-long program each Sunday night.  The "old folks" were exposed to Elvis and The Beatles and the youngsters heard Ella, Satchmo, The Mills Bros., etc.  We got a taste of everything - opera, Broadway musicals and plays, comics of all ages, magicians, acrobats, ballet, tap dancing, sports, classical as well as modern music and so much more. It was a liberal arts education in a 60 minute program.  
    These crosswords provide another means of opening one's mind.  I've learned so much through the years, but I also cherish all the knowledge I possess and am so happy to put that to good and fun-filled use.
     Happy solving and Happy Labor Day Weekend.  May the puzzles be with you!

Not to be picky, but years of television commercials taught me that [Dove] beauty bars are not SOAP, but rather ‚Äúone quarter cleansing cream‚Äù!

@deb Why is nothing more useful than an OWLET?

I nearly jumped out of my chair when I finally got the last one to fall: FROYO. I couldn‚Äôt figure out what letter should finish the word FRO_O. I was running through the alphabet and was about to give up when the puzzle was marked complete! Frozen yogurt, of course! Great puzzle!
I doubt I've ever seen it in print, but GROADY with an A is how I would spell it. And a bigwig in the Jarheads certainly outranks every NCO.

Nothing GRODY about today's puzzle‚Äîloved it!  I am unofficially counting it a Friday best because I had help on what is officially listed as Friday best‚Äîwhereas this one was completely clean! Huzzah! And it was fun and lively! Had some slower for me spots but it all worked out. 

Seems I'm the only one here who didn't immediately put BRA STRAPS at 1A, but... I did try to stuff strapless bra in and left it for later when it didn't work.  

Never heard of a REFUSENIK before, I don't think and didn't know the Chicago team but the K seemed the most likely. VEEP STAKES was also new. Thank you, crosses!

I know there are a bunch of comments about this, but I admit I had the same reasoning as Deb about retirement/PIT STOP. I also remember having similar confusion in earlier puzzles. I never think of retiring cars, only changing tires. As usual, I hope writing this helps me retain that misdirection for future puzzles.

Favorite - by far - was DOG EARED! What an absolute delight!! 
Also loved GRODY (so glad I went for it instead of GROss!), CAT TOY, UMPS, GARISH (great word!), Handles differently for RENAMES... I guess there really wasn't anything I didn't like, including the handful of answers I didn't know. 

I'm used to getting a Gee whiz or Aw, shucks or whatever at the end but this one went straight to happy music!  

And now, I should make like an ANT and an UMP and get back to working industriously at home! 

Cheers to the weekend, all!!  :-)
Great Caesar's ghost, can we agree on spelling?

I had a somewhat embarrassing "one final letter mistake," as I call it. I wasn't sure what "Marked Twain?" meant, but I had filled 39D as ER NURSE, and DEGEARED was in the dictionary, so I just left it at that and went about the rest of the puzzle. Only once the "Something's amiss" message had popped up did I trawl through the grid and find my mistake. Oops!
Ahem! No one from 2nd Lt. to Potus "out ranks" a USMC NCO! Just sayin.' Great puzzle!

Just now finishing.  A hard one, though I finished slightly under my average time.  At one point, I had the entire top half completely filled and nothing filled in the bottom half.  Then I got the SE quarter completely filled, and nothing in the SW quarter.  Then once I got DOGEARED (a difficult, but clever clue) and then DEARGOD, the rest fell into place.   Very satisfying.

Please correct me if I'm wrong (or overly pedantic), but for 45-across, isn't it inaccurate to say Greek myth?  I believe the Cupid and Psyche story is only known from the Roman source by Apuleius and never used the name Eros, only Cupid... so it would technically be Roman myth and require a different clue, no?  No evidence that it was ever a Greek myth.

I suspect the maker intended the "retirement" clue to refer to the fact that race cars get new tires when they pull off the racecourse into the Pit, thus making a Pit Stop.
(The "time for sleep" explanation is not wrong, but I don't think it hits the mark.)  :-)
@Deb:  A pit stop in an automotive race is when new tires are installed before the car is sent out for more laps. Hence, the car is re-tired.
Oof. Tough. I completed it with the obscure answers‚Ä¶

Okay, the big PLOT HOLE for me in Star Wars is...how exactly is LEIA a princess? (There may be spoilers following for some folks here.) Sure, she's the daughter of Queen Amidala, but Padme's title was ceremonial, and not hereditary. Also, that would have made Luke a prince. By the time the twins are born, Padme is a Senator, not the Queen. So then Leia is adopted by Bail Organa, also a Senator, but nobody ever called him 'Prince." Yes, the folks at Wookiepedia say he's a member of Alderaan's royal family, but if it wasn't in the movies, it didn't happen. By the time of A New Hope, Leia has replaced her father as Senator, which is all academic when Darth Vader blows up Alderaan. Ergo, Leia is not a 'Disney Princess.'

One more thing: the iconic golden bikini was sold at auction for $175,000.
Good, challenging Friday. Broke a light sweat.
Great puzzle. Hard as I‚Äôve seen. I needed help in the NE. Oh, well.

A REFUSENIK does NOT denote ‚Äúdefiant protestor.‚Äù 

This usage (as applied in the puzzle) is obscure, and it unfortunately obfuscates what many people know as the most common usage: (from Wikipedia:) ‚ÄúRefusenik, or Refusnik, was an unofficial term for individuals‚Äîtypically, but not exclusively, Soviet Jews‚Äîwho were denied permission to emigrate, primarily to Israel, by the authorities of the Soviet Union and other countries of the Soviet Bloc. The term refusenik is derived from the "refusal" handed down to a prospective emigrant from the Soviet authorities.‚Äù

Yet again the NYT crossword fails to include basic history of the Jews and other marginalized people in designing its answers and clues. Many of those ‚Äúrefuseniks‚Äù finally found peace by getting to Israel, the only place that would give them safety. My grandmother helped many through a Soviet Jewry assistance program in Miami in the 1980s.

And to be clear, the Jewish people were not the ‚Äúdefiant protestor‚Äùs; they were defiantly treated with antisemitism by the nation that helped spread the lie that Zionism was ‚Äúcolonization,‚Äù a lie that continues to be used to harass Jews today.

Hard, but a satisfying finish.  Took concentration and lots of alternative meanings.  Great brain work out. I really enjoyed this Friday puzzle, even though I'm not a fan of the "made up" slang words. They are so very specific to demographics, that they are hard to unwrap.  I don't know many of  them, thus  have to suss  them out.  Which is good for the puzzling, so not gonna complain,  Just note.  This very nice puzzle from  Colin Adams  had a few of those bugaboos (slang? Not in my vernacular).

Happy cross-wording folks from a rainy week end in Texas!  May your labor be filled with satisfying moments! Cheers.

The easy mode clue for 33A is wrong, or at any rate not "famously" right. Since 1950s Biff didn't use the Almanac until 1958 (three years later), it stands to reason that the future that old Biff travels to is the same future as he left - the "branching" to the Biff timeline won't happen for another three years.
2 stars at best.
Had a tough time with 41D DIERDRE since I know nothing of Irish folklore.  Although I've seen 43D YOINKED before, it's still a fun word.  Kind of a party in your mouth.  Nice puzzle.
Great puzzle!  I miss the vertex!!!
I suggest possibly that for 8D, "retirement" doesn't actually mean sleep (though that was also my first thought), but rather replacing all the tires, something commonly done at a literal pit stop...
Thanks, Colin, for the fun fill!

Fun Friday that I really enjoyed! Just one minor correction in that 5D was not first used by Ivan the Great (Ivan III), but by his grandson Ivan the Terrible (Ivan IV) after his conquest of Kazan in 1552. That said, the Russian word we translate as ‚Äúterrible‚Äù can also mean ‚Äúawe inspiring‚Äù which I suppose is close enough to ‚Äúgreat,‚Äù if only a ‚Äúgreat‚Äù hadn‚Äôt ruled before him.

I enjoyed this puzzle...lots of clever clues/misdirects. As soon as I filled in PIT STOP, I immediately thought of changing tires and was impressed with that clue in particular. I was stuck in the east, though, because I put COAT for the Scottish new year present, to represent keeping warm. That seemed reasonable, but then OH TOR_? No idea about the Tower of Hanoi, so I filled in RISK as an element, and then OH TORR? No. Rethinking the Tower of Hanoi, it occurred to me it could be a physical DISK, and then we have OH TORD, which led right to OH LORD! And ohhhhh!!! COAL also keeps you warm! üòÄ I really had fun with this one. 

PS I did not know YOINKED, so thank you for the comments column which helped me with that one.
Yoinked???
Retirement is something done at a pit stop during long auto races, more commonly called changing tires.
@Steve L Thanks - I would have added that if you hadn't already. Besides, in non-racing context, a PIT STOP isn't a place to sleep... it's a restroom visit.

@Steve L Exactly what I was thinking
Plus sometimes cars go into the pits and, for whatever mechanical reason, don't come back out... retiring from the race.

@Steve L 

I knew I could count on you to bring it up.

That's how I, too, read into that misdirect. 

The only other way I use PIT STOP is if I'm on my way somewhere but make a quick stop on the way there, a dash-in-dash-out kind of thing, much like race cars quickly getting their tires changed. 

That said, I'm sure many will, like Deb, see it from the angle of retiring somewhere for the night on a road trip, and I suppose it's fine. If it got them to PIT STOP, I don't see how the it can be an entirely faulted interpretation.

@Pani Korunova 

When we travel places, we walk around as much as possible, to get a true feel of a place. When we tried doing that in the US, we were amazed how pedestrian-unfriendly the towns and cities were. And we were the only ones walking anywhere! We also got the feeling Americans think public transport is for rejects only - nobody encouraged us to use it. In Warsaw you meet people from all walks of life on buses, trams and the metro - students, managers, office workers, clerks etc. In a San Francisco bus we only met people from the fringes of society. It was very weird.

@R.J. Smith 

I think the real mistake was thinking that the others weren‚Äôt real crossword puzzles. 

Fridays and Saturdays are almost always straightforward albeit difficult themeless puzzles. The only exceptions are very occasional commemorative or holiday puzzles. 

Thursdays are almost always tricky, involving rebuses and other tricks. But all themed puzzles, that is, Sunday through Thursday, can have tricks or features like circles or shaded squares. 

The fact that you don‚Äôt consider them proper crossword puzzles is just your opinion. Most subscribers would disagree with you.  That‚Äôs why they subscribe to the NYT puzzles.

@Min 

That‚Äôs an interesting theory. I vaguely remember watching the Ed Sullivan Show when I was in grade school.

But it‚Äôs important to note a couple of things. I think far fewer households had multiple TVs back then. And even if they did, there were far fewer viewing options available. Both factors increased the likelihood that a family would watch the show together. 

I‚Äôm 65. I don‚Äôt always know the cultural references from generations that grew up after I did, but I appreciate learning some of them from crosswords.

@Min

There‚Äôs something to what you say, but in this internet era there are still many opportunities for people to stay culturally connected across generations. Those who are truly intellectually curious will stay abreast of current trends and be aware of history.  The trick is to not dismiss the past as irrelevant or treat the present as something to be avoided.  One benefit of the modern online world is that crosswords, which for me were for decades a largely solitary endeavor, can now be shared with a wonderful community of enthusiasts like this one.

The original meaning of fast in English has nothing to do with speed, but with firmness and security:
to hold fast
to tie fast
to make fast
all of which can be replaced in modern English by
‚Äúfasten‚Äù.
Think also ‚Äústeadfast‚Äù (staying firmly in place), ‚Äúcolorfast‚Äù (meaning dyes that don‚Äôt run or bleach).

Fast is pure, unadulterated English, and worth knowing and - if you are a language lover - loving.
